title: Word of the Day: inedible
description: This word has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content:
The word inedible has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 9 in “Over 200 Children Hospitalized in China After School Serves Lead-Tainted Food,” by David Pierson and Berry Wang:

The police in Tianshui, a city in Gansu Province, have detained eight officials and employees of the privately owned kindergarten, including the principal and an investor. They found that school cooks used inedible pigments bought online to decorate buns and cakes that were served to the children, Chinese state media reported on Tuesday.

Can you correctly use the word inedible in a sentence?

Based on the definition and example provided, write a sentence using today’s Word of the Day and share it as a comment on this article. It is most important that your sentence makes sense and demonstrates that you understand the word’s definition, but we also encourage you to be creative and have fun.

If you want a better idea of how inedible can be used in a sentence, read these usage examples on Vocabulary.com. You can also visit this guide to learn how to use IPA symbols to show how different words are pronounced.

If you enjoy this daily challenge, try our vocabulary quizzes.
summary: The word inedible has been featured on numerous occasions in the past year, including in an article by David Pierson and Berry Wang. The police in Tianshui, China, have detained eight officials and employees at a privately-run kindergarten, including the principal and an investor, for using ineditable pigments in buns and cakes served to children. The challenge involves using the definition and example of the word inevitable.
shortSummary: The inedibility of ineditable is the word inescapic, a phrase many people refer to as "Heck" (We're Not) but "Sheesh" (Heck)

argos_summary: The term 'inedible' has been highlighted in recent articles, particularly in a report about over 200 children in China being hospitalized due to lead-tainted food served at a kindergarten. Authorities have detained several officials from the school after discovering that inedible pigments were used in food preparation. The article encourages readers to creatively use the word 'inedible' in sentences, while also promoting vocabulary quizzes related to various topics.
